{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = The Adventures of Barry McKenzie | image = Barrymckenzie.jpg | caption = UK 30th Anniversary DVD | writer = Bruce Beresford,
[[Barry Humphries]] | based on = the comic strip by Barry Humphries drawn by Nicholas Garland | starring = [[Barry Crocker]],
Barry Humphries,
[[Spike Milligan]],
[[Peter Cook]] | director = [[Bruce Beresford]] | producer = [[Phillip Adams]] | cinematography = [[Donald McAlpine]] | editing = John Scott, William Anderson | studio = Longford Productions | distributor = Phillip Adams
Columbia Pictures Video Ltd. | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1972|10|12}} | runtime = 114 minutes | language = English | country = Australia | music = [[Peter Best (composer)|Peter Best]] | awards = | budget = A$250,000Andrew Pike and Ross Cooper, ''Australian Film 1900–1977: A Guide to Feature Film Production'', Melbourne: Oxford University Press, 1998 p265 }} '''''The Adventures of Barry McKenzie''''' is a 1972 Australian film starring [[Barry Crocker]], telling the story of an Australian '[[Yob (slang)|yobbo]]' on his travels to the United Kingdom. [[Barry McKenzie]] was originally a character created by [[Barry Humphries]] for a [[cartoon strip]] in ''[[Private Eye]]''. It was the first Australian film to surpass one million dollars in Australian box office receipts.Don Groves, [http://www.sbs.com.au/movies/article/2010/03/23/beresford-reflects-his-colossal-mistake "Beresford reflects on his 'colossal mistake': A TV screening of an iconic Australian comedy brings back mixed memories for the filmmaker."] [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]], 23 March 2010. A sequel, ''[[Barry McKenzie Holds His Own]]'', was produced in 1974.{{cite web|title = Australianscreen.com.au – The Adventures of Barry McKenzie |url =http://aso.gov.au/titles/features/adventures-barry-mckenzie/ |accessdate=22 December 2008|work= |publisher=National Film and Sound Archive}} Barry Humphries appears in several roles, including: a hippie, Barry McKenzie's psychiatrist Doctor de Lamphrey, and as Aunt Edna Everage (later [[Dame Edna Everage]]). Humphries would later achieve fame with the character of Dame Edna in the UK and USA. The film was produced by [[Phillip Adams]], who became a prominent [[op-ed]] journalist and broadcaster, and directed by [[Bruce Beresford]]. ==Plot summary== Barry 'Bazza' McKenzie (Barry Crocker) travels to England with his aunt Edna Everage (Barry Humphries) to advance his cultural education. Bazza is a young Aussie fond of beer, [[Bondi Beach, New South Wales|Bondi]] and beautiful '[[sheila]]s'. He settles in [[Earls Court]], where his old friend Curly ([[Paul Bertram]]) has a flat. He gets drunk, is ripped off, insulted by pretentious Englishmen and exploited by record producers, religious charlatans and a BBC television producer ([[Peter Cook]]). He reluctantly leaves England under the orders of his aunt, after exposing himself on television. His final words on the plane home are, "I was just starting to like the Poms!" ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Barry Crocker]] as Barry McKenzie *[[Barry Humphries]] as Aunt Edna/Hoot/Meyer de Lamphrey *[[Peter Cook]] as Dominic *[[Spike Milligan]] as landlord *[[Dick Bentley]] as detective *[[Dennis Price]] as Mr Gort *[[Julie Covington]] as Blance *[[Avice Landone]] as Mrs Gort *[[Joan Bakewell]] as herself *Paul Bertram as Curly *[[Mary Ann Severne|Mary Anne Severne]] as Lesley *[[Jonathan Hardy]] as Groove Courtney *[[Jenny Tomasin]] as Sarah Gort *Chris Malcolm as Sean *[[Judith Furse]] as Claude *Maria O'Brien as Caroline Thighs *John Joyce as Maurie Miller *Margo Lloyd as Mrs McKenzie *Brian Tapply as avant-garde composer *[[John Clarke (satirist)|John Clarke]] as an underground filmmaker *Wilfred Grove as customs officer *[[Willie Rushton|William Rushton]] as man on plane *[[Bernard Spear]] as taxi driver *[[Jack Watling]] as TV director *[[Alexander Archdale]] *[[Clive James]] as man passed out at party (uncredited) {{div col end}} ==Production== Bruce Beresford was living in London and knew Barry Humphries socially when he heard about government funding being given to Australian films.
I said to Barry Humphries that we should do a script from the comic strip because they had money available to make films but it hadn't occurred to them that they had no one to make them. I said, "I don't think they've thought about that but if we whip back to Australia with a script, with you starring in it and we're all set to go, we have a good chance of getting the money. There wouldn't be all that many going for it." And that's more or less what happened.[http://www.signis.net/malone/tiki-index.php?page=Bruce+Beresford&bl "Interview with Bruce Beresford", ''Signet'', 15 May 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121220180451/http://www.signis.net/malone/tiki-index.php?page=Bruce+Beresford&bl |date=20 December 2012 }} accessed 17 November 2012
The film was entirely funded by the [[Screen Australia|Australian Film Development Corporation]]. Shooting started in London in January 1972, with the unit moving to Australia in February. Local unions complained about the presence of British technicians in the crew, but a compromise was reached where Australian technicians joined the crew. Filming ended in March. Phillip Adams wanted to cast [[Paul Hogan]] as Curly but he turned down the role. "I suspect he was concerned over his ability to work with professional actors," says Adams.Gordon Glenn & Scott Murray, "Phil Adams: Producer", ''Cinema Papers'', March–April 1976 p340 ==Release== Phillip Adams insisted on distributing the film himself initially.David Stratton, ''The Last New Wave: The Australian Film Revival'', Angus & Robertson, 1980 p44 The film was very popular at the box office in Australia and London, and the production company repaid the government most of its money within three months of release. Bruce Beresford said in a 1999 interview:
Personally, it was a massive mistake for me to do it, a massive mistake, because the film was so badly received critically. Instead of getting me work, even though it was successful commercially, it put me out of work.
Beresford went on to direct "Barry McKenzie Holds His Own" {{endash}} again to great commercial success {{endash}} in 1974, and then "Breaker Morant" starring Edward Woodward in 1980. However, in the 1999 interview Beresford said that both Barry McKenzie films had been "mistakes":
That [''Barry McKenzie Holds His Own''] was an even bigger mistake. I couldn't find anything else to make because the films were so reviled critically that I thought that, with these two films, I'll never work again. Luckily Phillip Adams saved my life by offering me Don's Party. But that was a couple of years later. I thought the Barry McKenzie films were very funny but the reaction was so hostile that I realised very quickly that I had made a massive mistake.
==Box office== This was the first Australian film to surpass $1 million at the national box office, and it led the Australian box office in 1972.Ben Davies, [http://www.spectator.co.uk/australia/6051553/our-lost-golden-age/ "Our lost Golden Age"], ''[[The Spectator]]'', 2 June 2010. The film recovered its $250,000 budget within a few months of release.A [[Film Victoria]] report on box office results states that ''The Adventures of Barry McKenzie'' took $47,000 at the box office in Australia, which is equivalent to $399,500 in 2009 dollars. [http://film.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/AA4_Aust_Box_office_report.pdf ''Film Victoria - Australian Films at the Australian Box Office''], archive copy [https://web.archive.org/web/20110218045303/http://film.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/AA4_Aust_Box_office_report.pdf here]. However, this figure may be an error, since it is inconsistent with the many other sources that describe the film as a major box office success that recouped its $250,000 budget in a few months. See also the notes at the entry for [http://www.ozmovies.com.au/movie/adventures-of-barry-mckenzie ''The Adventures of Barry McKenzie''] at Oz Movies, raising similar doubts about the Film Victoria box office figures. ==Themes== The film explores the cultural distance between Australian [[popular culture]] and the manners and mores of England, both nations presented in hyperbolically satirical manner. Barry is the extreme embodiment of "Ockerism" of the late fifties and mid-sixties Australia. Swearing, excessive drinking, vomiting, rowdiness and other crassness is glorified. The film also plays with the ideas of the era where the sixties cultural revolution had swept aside the "certainties" of [[Classical education movement|classical education]].{{cn|date=August 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0068173}} * [http://australianscreen.com.au/titles/adventures-barry-mckenzie/ ''The Adventures of Barry McKenzie''] at [[Australian Screen Online]] * [http://bazza_fan.tripod.com/ ""Barry Mckenzie fan site""] *[http://www.ozmovies.com.au/movie/adventures-of-barry-mckenzie ''The Adventures of Barry McKenzie''] at Oz Movies {{Bruce Beresford}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adventures Of Barry Mckenzie, The}} [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:1972 films]] [[Category:Australian comedy films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films based on Australian comics]] [[Category:Films directed by Bruce Beresford]] [[Category:Live-action films based on comics]]

{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=February 2011}} {{COI|date=February 2011}} }} {{Infobox museum |name = The Children's Museum
متحف الأطفال الاردن |image = Children Museum Amman 1.JPG |imagesize = |caption = |alt = |map_type = |map_caption = |map_alt = |coordinates = {{coord|31.984037|35.825858|display=inline}} |established = 2007{{cite news |first=Dale |last=Gavlak |title=Jordan opens children's museum |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6595425.stm |date=2007-04-26 |publisher=BBC News }} |dissolved = |location = [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] |type = [[Children's museum]] |visitors = |director = Mrs Sawsan Dalaq |publictransit = |website = http://www.cmj.jo/ }} The '''Children's Museum Jordan''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: متحف الاطفال الاردن) is a [[children's museum]] in [[Amman]], [[Jordan]]. It is located in [[Al Hussein Public Parks]]. Launched in 2007, the museum is a member of the [[Association of Children's Museums]] and [[Hands On! International]]. The Museum’s total build area of 7,348 square meters includes: 150 interactive indoor and outdoor exhibits, an art studio, a library, a multipurpose hall, an outdoor theatre, a restaurant with an adjunct party room and a gift shop. On standby are additional spaces with potential for development, such as the exhibit hall extension, a botanical garden annex or the special effects auditorium. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cmj.jo Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Children's Museum Jordan}} [[Category:Children's museums|Jordan]] [[Category:Museums established in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Jordan]] [[Category:Museums in Amman]] [[Category:Child-related organisations in Jordan]] {{Jordan-struct-stub}} {{museum-stub}}

A timeline of notable events relating to [[BBC Radio 2]], a British national radio station which began broadcasting in September 1967.
==1960s==
*'''1967''' **30 September – Radio 2 launches at 5.30{{nbsp}}am, replacing the [[BBC Light Programme]] which had stopped broadcasting three-and-a-half hours earlier. [[BBC Radio 1]] launches 90 minutes later.
*'''1968''' **No events.
*'''1969''' **28 April – The first edition of soap opera ''[[Waggoners' Walk]]'' is broadcast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1969-04-28|title=BBC Radio 2 – 28 April 1969 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **11 June – ''[[The Organist Entertains]]'', presented by [[Robin Richmond]], is broadcast for the first time. **Unknown – ''[[Dance Band Days]]'' is broadcast for the first time.
==1970s==
*'''1970''' **3 April – ''[[Any Questions]]'' is broadcast on Radio 2 for the final time. **4 April – Following the transfer of BBC Radio’s sports coverage from [[BBC Radio 3]] to Radio 2, the first edition of ''[[5 live Sport|Sport on 2]]'' is broadcast. **5 April – ''[[Your Hundred Best Tunes]]'' moves to the station from [[BBC Radio 4]]. **The first voice to be heard on Radio 2, [[Paul Hollingdale]], leaves.
*'''1971''' **August – [[Eric Robinson (conductor)|Eric Robinson]] hosts ''[[Melodies for You]]'' for the final time. ** 4 November – Radio 2 (and Radio 4) begin broadcasting in stereo in South East England. Stereo was rolled out to the rest of the country over subsequent years.<ref>Brown, Ron [https://books.google.com/books?id=4hD8LSniK3MC&pg=PA264&lpg=PA264&dq=%22new+scientist%22+%22steam+radio+comes+up+to+date%22&source=bl&ots=P9kqcfb0xX&sig=SCWoacYUkg0nj99ii_NctuAJMDM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xuLGU-WGLeuf7Ab2n4HoBA&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22new%20scientist%22%20%22steam%20radio%20comes%20up%20to%20date%22&f=false "Steam radio comes up to date"], ''New Scientist'' 2 November 1972, p. 264</ref>
*'''1972''' **3 April – [[Terry Wogan]] joins from [[BBC Radio 1]] to present a new weekday [[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show|breakfast show]]. He replaces [[John Churchill Dunn|John Dunn]], who moves to afternoons. ''Breakfast Special'' disappears from the airwaves at this point. Also a new early show is introduced, resulting in Radio 2 starting the day on weekdays and Saturdays 30 minutes earlier, at 5{{nbsp}}am – Sunday broadcasting still commenced at just before 7{{nbsp}}am. **1 October – [[Sam Costa]] replaces [[Kenneth Alwyn]] as host of ''[[Melodies for You]]''. Kenneth had hosted the show since the start of the year.
*'''1973''' **2 July – ''[[Woman's Hour]]'' is transferred from [[BBC Radio 2]] to [[BBC Radio 4]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1973-06-29|title=BBC Radio 2 – 29 June 1973 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> and [[Jimmy Young (broadcaster)|Jimmy Young]] transfers to Radio 2 from Radio 1. **[[Colin Berry]] joins as an announcer, newsreader and occasional presenter. **[[Simon Bates]] joins.
*'''1974''' **29 September – [[David Jacobs (broadcaster)|David Jacobs]] replaces [[Sam Costa]] as host of ''[[Melodies for You]]''.
*'''1975''' **6 January – Broadcasting hours are reduced due to budget cuts at the BBC. The former 5{{nbsp}}am{{snd}}2{{nbsp}}am schedule is reduced to a 6{{nbsp}}am start up Mondays to Saturdays, 6:55{{nbsp}}am on Sundays, and an earlier closedown time of around 12:33{{nbsp}}am each day. The cuts also see the weekday afternoon show, presented by [[David Hamilton (broadcaster)|David Hamilton]], broadcast on both Radio 1 and Radio 2. **29 September – ***The station closes slightly earlier, concluding its day at around 12:10{{nbsp}}am Mondays to Fridays, and at 12:33{{nbsp}}am on Saturdays and Sundays. ***Radio 2 stops being available on VHF/FM for an hour on weeknights when it lends its VHF/FM frequencies to Radio 1 between 11pm and midnight. Previously, it had been available on Long Wave only (apart from some VHF simulcasts on [[BBC Local Radio]] stations) between 10pm and midnight between October 1971 and December 1974, when various [[progressive rock]] shows on Radio 1 were given the higher-quality waveband.
*'''1976''' **January – [[Simon Bates]] leaves, and later in the year he starts broadcasting on Radio 1. **4 October – [[John Churchill Dunn|John Dunn]] replaces [[Sam Costa]] as host of the drivetime programme. **[[Sarah Kennedy]] begins her first stint at the station.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/shows/kennedy/biography.shtml|title=BBC Radio 2 – Sarah Kennedy|work=BBC|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref>
*'''1977''' **4 April – From tonight, Radio 1 'borrows' Radio 2's VHF/FM frequencies for two hours each weeknight – between 10pm and midnight. **28 November – [[David Hamilton (broadcaster)|David Hamilton]] afternoon show is now heard on Radio 2 only following the withdrawal of the 1975 economy measures which seen his show being simulcast on both Radios 1 and 2.
*'''1978''' **[[Brian Matthew]] takes Radio 2 ''Round Midnight'' for the first time. **1 April – Broadcasting hours are extended to a 5{{nbsp}}am{{snd}}2{{nbsp}}am schedule when the budget restrictions were eased, and the pre 1975 broadcasting hours are re-introduced. **23 November – ***Radio 2 moves from 1500m (200 kHz) long wave to 433 & 330m (693 & 909 kHz) medium wave as part of a plan to improve national AM reception, and to conform with the [[Geneva Frequency Plan of 1975]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frequencyfinder.org.uk/History_Transmission.pdf|title = History of Radio Transmission in the UK|publisher= Frequency Finder}}</ref> ***The [[shipping forecast]] transfers from [[BBC Radio 2]] to [[BBC Radio 4]] so that the forecast can continue to be broadcast on [[long wave]].
*'''1979''' **27 January – [[BBC Radio 2]] closes down for the final time, and at 5{{nbsp}}am Radio 2 begins continuous broadcasting with ''You and the Night and the Music'' filling the overnight hours.
==1980s== *'''1980''' **13 January – ''[[Family Favourites]]'' is broadcast for the final time. **3 March – [[Nigel Ogden]] replaces [[Robin Richmond]] as host of ''[[The Organist Entertains]]''. **30 May – The final edition of soap opera ''[[Waggoners' Walk]]'' is broadcast. **[[Ed Stewart]] joins to present the weekday afternoon programme.
*'''1981''' **4 October – ''All Time Greats'' with [[Desmond Carrington]] is broadcast for the first time. **[[Sam Costa]] leaves.
*'''1982''' **3 December – Radio 2 is simulcast on Radio 1 for the final time.
*'''1983''' **4 January – [[BBC Radio 2]] revives ''[[Music While You Work]]''. **12 February – ''[[Sounds of the 60s]]'' is broadcast for the first time. The show is presented by [[Keith Fordyce]].
*'''1984''' **20 January – Ahead of changes to the schedule, following the decision not to renew the contract of long standing presenter [[Ed Stewart]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wPU9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=C0kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6356,3647518&dq=ed-stewart%20radio&hl=en|title=The Glasgow Herald – Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref> the year-long revival of ''[[Music While You Work]]'' ends and [[Gloria Hunniford]] takes over Ed’s slot the following week. [[Steve Jones (game show presenter)|Steve Jones]] replaces Gloria on the lunchtime show. Other changes see a new overnight programme, ''[[Night Ride (BBC Radio 2)|Nightride]]'', replacing ''You and the Night and the Music''. [[Pete Murray (DJ)|Pete Murray]] leaves and is replaced on his Saturday late show by [[Ken Bruce]], who gets his first regular slot, and ''Sounds of Jazz'' moves to Radio 2 from Radio 1. **28 December – [[Terry Wogan]] ends his first run as presenter of ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1984-12-28|title=BBC Radio 2 – 28 December 1984 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref>
*'''1985''' **7 January – [[Ken Bruce]] takes over ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]'' and [[David Jacobs (broadcaster)|David Jacobs]], who had presented ''[[Melodies for You]]'' since 1974, launches a new weekday lunchtime programme consisting mainly of tracks from [[musical theatre]] called ''My Kind of Music''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1985-01-07|title=BBC Radio 2 – 7 January 1985 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> He replaces [[Steve Jones (game show presenter)|Steve Jones]] who takes over the Saturday late show slot vacated by Ken Bruce although by July, [[Martin Kelner]] had taken over the slot. Robin Boyle replaces David Jacobs as host of ''[[Melodies for You]]''. **Radio 2 changes the format of ''[[Sounds of the 60s]]''. The show is no longer hosted by a single presenter and instead a different artist from the era presents the programme each week. **[[Steve Jones (game show presenter)|Steve Jones]] leaves.
*'''1986''' **7 April – ***[[Derek Jameson]] takes over ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]'' from [[Ken Bruce]], who moves to mid-mornings. ***The weekday daytime schedule gives way to evening programmes an hour earlier, at 7{{nbsp}}pm. **13 April – [[Richard Baker (broadcaster)|Richard Baker]] replaces Robin Boyle as host of ''[[Melodies for You]]''. **December – [[David Hamilton (broadcaster)|David Hamilton]] leaves. He says that his reason for going is because the music policy had become “geriatric” following a repositioning of the station, under the influence of new Head of Music [[Frances Line]], to appeal to over 50s with a playlist of nostalgia, easy listening and light music.
*'''1987''' **No events.
*'''1988''' **January – Sport bulletins are broadcast at breakfast for the first time. Previously, apart from a racing bulletin, sports news did not commence until lunchtime. **[[Chris Stuart]] replaces [[Ray Moore (broadcaster)|Ray Moore]] as presenter of the early show when the latter is struck down by cancer. Moore had presented the show since 1980; Stuart, previously breakfast presenter on [[BBC Radio Wales]], has often covered for Moore since 1985. [[Graham Knight (broadcaster)|Graham Knight]] joins to present the weekend early shows. **29 September – [[BBC Radio 1]] 'borrows' [[BBC Radio 2]]'s FM frequencies on a weeknight for the final time following the start of a programme of switching on transmitters to allow Radio 1 to broadcast full-time on FM which, at this time, was available to 2/3 of the UK.
*'''1989''' **[[Simon Dee]] presents ''[[Sounds of the 60s]]'' for the first half of the year. **1 October – [[BBC Radio 2]] begins a series of Sunday afternoon performances of works by [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]. The 12-week series, which runs until Christmas, replaces the station’s usual Sunday afternoon schedule.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1989-10-01 |work=BBC Genome Project |title=BBC Radio 2 listings 1 October 1989 |accessdate=22 July 2017}}</ref>
==1990s== *'''1990''' **6 January – [[BBC Radio 2]] becomes available on FM on Saturday afternoons for the first time; a new music schedule is created, with [[Katie Boyle]] presenting a two-hour programme, while sport continues on MW. **25 March – At 7{{nbsp}}pm [[BBC Radio 2]] becomes available on FM 24/7 for the first time after the final ever ‘borrow’ of its FM frequencies by [[BBC Radio 1]]. **30 March – Ahead of major changes to the station’s output, [[Brian Matthew]] goes ''Round Midnight'' for the final time. **31 March – As part of the changes a weekend late night Arts Programme and ''[[Sounds of the 50s]]'', presented by [[Ronnie Hilton]], are launched with Brian Matthew taking over as host of ''[[Sounds of the 60s]]''. **2 April – The changes to weekday programming begin today. [[Ken Bruce]] launches a new late night programme with [[Judith Chalmers]] replacing Ken at mid-mornings, a weeknight late night jazz show called ''Jazz Parade'' is launched as a replacement for ''Sounds of Jazz'' and a weekday guest afternoon slot is introduced featuring a different personality choosing their favourite music each week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1990-04-02|title=BBC Radio 2 – 2 April 1990 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **15 August – [[BBC Radio 2]] begins to wind down its transmissions on MW ahead of the launch of [[BBC Radio 5 (former)|BBC Radio 5]], which will occupy Radio 2’s MW frequencies, by broadcasting a daytime information service providing advice about how to listen to Radio 2 on FM. **26 August – Sport is broadcast on Radio 2 for the final time. **27 August – Radio 2 becomes the first national radio station in the UK to broadcast only on FM. **16 September – ''[[The Sunday Hour|Sunday Half Hour]]'' is revamped. Instead of coming from a different church each week, the show becomes a studio-based programme with [[Roger Royle]] as presenter.
*'''1991''' **20 December – [[Derek Jameson]] leaves ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]'' after presenting for five years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1991-12-20|title=BBC Radio 2 – 20 December 1991 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> and the final weekday lunchtime serving of ''My Kind of Music'' takes place.
*'''1992''' **6 January – In a major shake-up of the daytime schedule, [[Brian Hayes (broadcaster)|Brian Hayes]] takes over ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]'' from [[Derek Jameson]] who moves to a new late evening slot to launch a new show, co-presented by his wife. [[Ken Bruce]] returns to the mid-morning show following [[Judith Chalmers]]’ departure and [[Ed Stewart]], who rejoined the station the previous year, takes over as the mid-afternoon presenter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1992-01-06|title=BBC Radio 2 – 6 January 1992 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> Weekend changes see ''[[Melodies for You]]'' move to early evenings and [[Barbara Sturgeon]] replaces [[Graham Knight (broadcaster)|Graham Knight]] as presenter of the weekend early shows. The weekday music policy is slightly adjusted; Sunday afternoon output is branded ''Vintage Years'', while [[John Sachs]] presents a Sunday morning show with a comparatively modern playlist compared to most of the station's other output at the time. **April – [[Alex Lester]] becomes the permanent early morning presenter (a slot previously hosted on rotation by the station's announcers and newsreaders) and in July Steve Madden becomes the permanent overnight presenter, a slot which had similarly been hosted by the presentation team on rotation since the late 1970s. **23 December – Brian Hayes presents ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]'' for the final time.
*'''1993''' **4 January – [[Terry Wogan]] returns to the breakfast slot with ''[[Wake Up to Wogan]]'' and [[Sarah Kennedy]] returns to the station to take over the early show, which later becomes known as ''The Dawn Patrol''.
*'''1994''' **[[Mo Dutta]] joins to present weekend early morning programmes, replacing [[Barbara Sturgeon]], and [[Martin Kelner]] rejoins after four years of only occasional appearances to present a Saturday afternoon programme and to stand in for other presenters. This Saturday show, along with documentaries and concerts broadcast after it, represents a tentative attempt to appeal more to the "[[The Beatles|Beatles]] generation", which the station is encouraged to appeal to in the 'People and Programmes' report published in February 1995.<ref>"Public sets a challenging programme: Corporation pledges to listen to audience views as consultation finds many feel sense of alienation", ''[[The Guardian]]'' page 2, 16 February 1995</ref>
*'''1995''' **Radio 2, along with the other national BBC stations, begins broadcasting via [[Digital Audio Broadcasting|DAB]], although it is some time before this is widely available. **21 April – [[Gloria Hunniford]] leaves; [[Debbie Thrower]] joins in June to begin a three-year early afternoon stint.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/9607c355252049deae5f164f50358a6c|title=Debbie Thrower – BBC Radio 2 – 12 June 1995 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **October – Following the death of [[Alan Dell]], [[Malcolm Laycock]] becomes presenter of ''[[Dance Band Days]]''. **19 November – Although he is still billed in ''Radio Times'' until 10 December, [[Charlie Chester]] is likely to have presented his last Radio 2 show on this day, before he had a stroke<ref>"Charlie Chester ill", ''[[The Times]]'' page 1, 23 November 1995</ref> after which he could not walk or speak.<ref>"Chester moves on", ''The Times'' page 26, 26 June 1996</ref>
*'''1996''' **March – [[James Moir|Jim Moir]] replaces [[Frances Line]] as controller and begins repositioning the station to attract a wider audience of over 35s, many of whom have moved to commercial radio following the repositioning of [[BBC Radio 1]] three years earlier. He introduces a daytime playlist consisting of AOR/contemporary music with specialist programmes airing during the evening and at the weekend. Nostalgic/easy listening music is restricted to Sundays only. The move is successful and people flock to the station and shortly after Radio 2 replaces Radio 1 as the most listened to station in the UK{{cn|date=August 2018}}. **30 March – [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]] joins to present weekend mid-morning shows. including launching ''Sunday Love Songs''. **July – [[Hugh Scully]] takes over as presenter of ''[[Melodies for You]]''. **6 October – The first edition of ''[[David Jacobs (broadcaster)|The David Jacobs Collection]]'' is broadcast on Sunday evenings. **29 November – [[Martin Kelner]] leaves.
*'''1997''' **29 March – [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] joins to present a Saturday late evening programme “for the discerning music fan”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1997-03-29|title=BBC Radio 2 – 29 March 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **3 April – Derek and Ellen Jameson present their late night programme for the final time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1997-04-03|title=BBC Radio 2 – 3 April 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> [[Richard Allinson]] takes over the late show from the following Monday. **5 April – ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'' returns to the BBC. The programme is aired on Saturday afternoons with [[Alan Freeman]] returning as host. The programme had last been on the BBC on [[BBC Radio 1]] at the end of 1992 and throughout most of the intervening period it had been broadcast on [[Capital Gold]]. **31 August – Regular programming on the BBC’s radio and television stations is abandoned to provide ongoing news coverage of the [[death of Diana, Princess of Wales]]. Radio [[BBC Radio 2|2]] airs a special programme from BBC Radio News, which is also carried on [[BBC Radio 3|3]], [[BBC Radio 4|4]] and [[BBC Radio 5 Live]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-26768473 |work=BBC News |title=Peter Allen: BBC 5 live should speak for the 'have-nots' |publisher=BBC |date=28 March 2014 |accessdate=28 March 2014}}</ref> Radio 2 broadcasts live coverage of the funeral six days later.
*'''1998''' **13 April – ''[[Dance Band Days]]'' is broadcast for the final time. **2 October – [[John Churchill Dunn|John Dunn]] presents his final drivetime show, having hosted the programme for 22 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1998-10-02|title=BBC Radio 2 – 2 October 1998 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **5 October – A major overhaul of the schedule sees many new faces joining the network, including the singer [[Katrina Leskanich]] and former [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]] presenter [[Lynn Parsons]], who present overnight shows on weekdays and weekends respectively, replacing Steve Madden and [[Charles Nove]]. [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] joins Radio 2 as a regular presenter hosting the afternoon drivetime show (Monday to Thursday) with [[Des Lynam]] presenting the show on Fridays. [[Sally Boazman]] becomes the station's first official traffic presenter and, the following April, [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] takes over a relaunched weekly country music programme from [[David Allan (broadcaster)|David Allan]].
*'''1999''' **26 April – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] is suspended from his drivetime show after allegations concerning a drug problem appeared in the Sunday tabloid, the ''[[News of the World]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/473589.stm|title= DJ fined over drugs offence|publisher= [[bbc.co.uk]]|date= 13 October 1999|accessdate= 2008-11-13}}</ref> [[Richard Allinson]] presents the drivetime show during Walker's absence, while [[Tom Robinson]] stands in on his Saturday afternoon show. **5 July – ''[[Steve Wright in the Afternoon]]'' returns to radio after a break of several years as [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]] replaces [[Ed Stewart]] as the weekday afternoon presenter. **1 August – [[Richard Baker (broadcaster)|Richard Baker]] begins his second stint as host of ''[[Melodies for You]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio2/1999-08-01|title=BBC Radio 2 – 1 August 1999 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **2 August – It is announced that [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] has signed [[BBC]] sports presenter [[Des Lynam]] on a four-year contract to become the company's main football presenter.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://212.58.226.17:8080/1/hi/uk/409897.stm|title= ITV signs Des Lynam|publisher= BBC News|date= 2 August 1999|accessdate= 19 December 2009}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> This means he will no longer present his Friday drivetime show. **14 October – Managers at Radio 2 reinstate Johnnie Walker after he is fined £2,000 by magistrates for admitting possession of cocaine.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/474586.stm|title= Drug case DJ reinstated|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|date= 14 October 1999|accessdate= 24 September 2012}}</ref> He returns to the air on 6 December.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/9ac222c77806401d8ce631d25b28d631 |title=Johnnie Walker – BBC Radio 2 – 6 December 1999 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref>
==2000s== *'''2000''' **February – [[BBC Radio 2]] presents its first annual ''[[BBC Radio 2 Folk Awards]]''. **3 April – [[Janice Long]] begins presenting the night time show. **21 October – The comedian [[Jack Docherty]] joins to host ''Saturday Night Jack''. The show lasts three months. **[[Dale Winton]] replaces [[Alan Freeman]] as host of ''[[Pick of the Pops]]''.
*'''2001''' **10 May – For the first time, Radio 2 becomes the UK's most listened to radio station, overtaking Radio 1. <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/may/10/broadcasting.bbc Radio 2 is top UK station]</ref> It has held that position ever since. **1 October – Radio 2 starts broadcasting a weekly album chart show. The one-hour programme is broadcast on Monday evenings and is presented by [[Simon Mayo]].<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/jul/20/broadcasting.bbc Simon Mayo to front Radio 2 album show]</ref>
*'''2002''' **11 March – Spin-off station [[BBC 6 Music]] launches. **20 December – Sir [[Jimmy Young (disc jockey)|Jimmy Young]] presents his final lunchtime programme after nearly 30 years with the network, and 50 years with the BBC.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/sir-jimmy-young-says-bye-for-good-at-last-but-adds-it-wasnt-my-idea-611674.html|title= Sir Jimmy Young says Bye For Good at last, but adds: 'It wasn't my idea'|publisher= The Independent|first= David|last= Lister|date= 21 December 2002|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref>
*'''2003''' **6 January – [[Jeremy Vine]] takes over [[Jimmy Young (disc jockey)|Jimmy Young]]'s old lunchtime show.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/2634619.stm|title= Vine on critics' wavelength|publisher= BBC News|date= 7 January 2003|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> **March – [[Richard Baker (broadcaster)|Richard Baker]] takes over as host of ''[[Your Hundred Best Tunes]]'' following the death of [[Alan Keith]]. Brian Kay briefly replaces Richard as host of ''[[Melodies for You]]'' with [[Sheridan Morley]] taking over the show the following year. **5 June – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] announces that he will be taking time off air to undergo treatment after being diagnosed with [[Non-Hodgkins lymphoma]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/2967298.stm|title= DJ Johnnie Walker in cancer battle|publisher= BBC News|date= 5 June 2003|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> During his time away the show is presented by [[Stuart Maconie]] and [[Noel Edmonds]] (who made a brief return to radio).
*'''2004''' **5 January – [[Lesley Douglas]] succeeds [[Jim Moir]] as Controller.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2003/oct/11/radio.arts|title=New controller takes over Radio 2|first=Alexis|last=Akwagyiram|date=11 October 2003|website=the Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **1 March – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] returns to his drivetime show following a nine-month break while he received treatment for cancer.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3493219.stm|title= DJ Walker back after cancer fight|publisher= BBC News|date= 15 February 2004|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> **7 June – [[Mark Radcliffe (radio broadcaster)|Mark Radcliffe]] joins and takes over the late show from [[Richard Allinson]] **28 August – ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'' ends although bank holiday editions of the show continue to be broadcast.
*'''2005''' **September – A year after [[BBC Radio 2]] stopped broadcasting a weekly edition of ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'', the programme returns on a regular basis. **[[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] joins and takes over Saturday afternoon.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/jul/06/bbc.radio|title=Evans signs seven-month contract with BBC|first=Julia|last=Day|date=6 July 2005|website=the Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref>
*'''2006''' **28 February – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] announces he will leave the Drivetime show after seven years. He will present his last show at the end of March.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4760328.stm|title= Drivetime DJ Walker to step down|publisher= BBC News|date= 28 February 2006|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> He presents his final programme on 31 March. **18 April – [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] takes over the ''[[Chris Evans Drivetime|Drivetime]]'' show from [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]].<ref name=Evans>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4766066.stm|title= Evans to host Radio 2 Drivetime|publisher= BBC News|date= 2 March 2006|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> **18 November – [[Russell Brand]] joins to present a [[The Russell Brand Show (radio show)|regular weekly programme]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2006/11/brand-new-show-for-r2/ |title=Brand new show for R2 |publisher=Radio Today |date=2 November 2006 |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref>
*'''2007''' **21 January – ''[[Your Hundred Best Tunes]]'' is broadcast for the final time. The programme ended after 47 years on air and was replaced a week later by ''[[Melodies for You]]'' with [[Alan Titchmarsh]] joining to present the programme.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2007/01/titchmarsh-gets-weekly-r2-show/ |title=Titchmarsh gets weekly R2 show |publisher=Radio Today |date=10 January 2007 |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> **4 April – [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] announces he will take a break from his shows while he receives treatment for prostate cancer. **8 April – [[Roger Royle]] presents ''[[The Sunday Hour|Sunday Half Hour]]'' for the final time, after 17 years as the programme’s host. He is replaced the following week by [[Brian D’Arcy]]. **16 April – The first ''[[Radcliffe and Maconie Show]]'' presented by [[Mark Radcliffe (radio broadcaster)|Mark Radcliffe]] and [[Stuart Maconie]] is aired on [[BBC Radio 2|Radio 2]]. **19 October – [[Michael Parkinson]] announces he will leave his Sunday morning show, ''[[Parkinson's Sunday Supplement]]'' after 11 years.<ref>{{Cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7053090.stm|title= Parkinson leaves his Radio 2 show|publisher= BBC News|date= 19 October 2007|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> He presented his last show in December.<ref>{{Cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7163710.stm|title= Parkinson bows out with honour|publisher= BBC News|date= 29 December 2007|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref>
*'''2008''' **17 March – [[Humphrey Lyttelton]] retires. He had presented ''Best of Jazz'' for the last 40 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/mar/12/bbc.radio|title=Humphrey Lyttelton retires from BBC Radio 2 jazz show after 40 years|first=Leigh|last=Holmwood|date=12 March 2008|website=the Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **16 October – An episode of the ''[[The Russell Brand Show (radio show)|Russell Brand Show]]'', co-hosted by fellow Radio 2 presenter [[Jonathan Ross]] is recorded for transmission at a later date. The show includes Brand and Ross leaving four prank messages on actor [[Andrew Sachs]]'s answerphone including offensive remarks about his granddaughter and use of foul language. The programme is subsequently broadcast on Saturday 18 October, partially censored, having passed the various pre-transmission checks from the programme's editors. Initially the programme only receives a negligible number of complaints regarding Jonathan Ross' bad language; however, after the incident is reported a week later by [[the Mail on Sunday]] a public outcry soon ensues. The case is referred to both [[Ofcom]] and the [[BBC Trust]] and in the interim Ross and Brand are both suspended for 12 weeks from all BBC programmes pending investigation. Soon after these announcements Russell Brand announces his resignation from the BBC shortly followed by Radio 2 controller [[Lesley Douglas]]. Jonathan Ross is suspended from the BBC without pay for 12 weeks.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=The ups and downs of Ross' career | date=30 October 2008 | publisher= | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7700656.stm | work =BBC News | pages = | accessdate =18 December 2009 | language = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Ross suspended for three months | date=30 October 2008 | publisher= | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7700816.stm | work =BBC News | pages = | accessdate =18 December 2009 | language = }}</ref> **30 October – Controller [[Lesley Douglas]]'s resignation is announced.
*'''2009''' **27 January – [[Bob Shennan]] is appointed as Controller following the resignation of [[Lesley Douglas]].<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jan/27/bob-shennan-named-radio-2-controller|title= Bob Shennan named Radio 2 controller|publisher= Guardian Media|date= 27 January 2009|accessdate= 18 December 2009 | location=London | first=Leigh | last=Holmwood}}</ref> He takes up the position in February. **13 March – The station confirms plans to overhaul its weekend schedule from April. This will include [[Paul O'Grady]], [[Alan Carr]] and [[Emma Forbes]] joining the network to present shows, while the Saturday afternoon comedy hour will move to Thursday evenings. The changes will also see [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] present ''[[Sounds of the Seventies#Johnnie Walker's Sounds of the 70s|Sounds of the 70s]]'' on Sunday afternoon.<ref>{{cite news|first=John |last=Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/mar/13/paul-ogrady-alan-carr-emma-forbes |title=Paul O'Grady, Alan Carr and Emma Forbes in at Radio 2 |publisher=guardian.co.uk |work=The Guardian |date=13 March 2009 |accessdate=1 February 2012}}</ref> **5 April – ***''[[Sounds of the 70s]]'' returns to the airwaves on a regular basis with [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] as presenter. The programme and been on air on an ad-hoc basis since 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/shows/sounds70s/|title= Sounds of the 70s|publisher= BBC Online}}</ref> *** [[Paul O'Grady]] presents his first Sunday teatime show as part of the weekend schedule changes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/mar/13/paul-ogrady-alan-carr-emma-forbes|title=Paul O'Grady, Alan Carr and Emma Forbes in at Radio 2|first=John|last=Plunkett|date=13 March 2009|website=the Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **22 May – The BBC says that Jonathan Ross's show will no longer be broadcast live following complaints about a joke he made on an edition of the programme which some listeners interpreted as being anti-gay.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/tv-radio/jonathan-ross-will-no-longer-record-live-after-gay-jibe-1689453.html|title= Jonathan Ross will no longer record live after gay jibe|publisher= The Independent|date= 22 May 2009|accessdate= 18 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref> **30 May – [[Mo Dutta]] leaves after 14 years of presenting weekend early shows for the station.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/may/27/zoe-ball-saturday-bbc-radio-2|title= Zoe Ball to host Saturday early breakfast show on Radio 2|publisher= The Guardian|first= John|last= Plunkett|date= 27 May 2009|accessdate= 18 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref> **31 May – Early weekend presenter [[Pete Mitchell (broadcaster)|Pete Mitchell]] leaves the station. **6 June – [[Zoë Ball]] and [[Emma Forbes]] join to present the Saturday and Sunday early show respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/may/27/zoe-ball-saturday-bbc-radio-2|title=Zoe Ball to host Saturday early breakfast show on Radio 2|first=John|last=Plunkett|date=27 May 2009|website=the Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **26 July – [[Malcolm Laycock]] presents his final edition of ''[[Sunday Night at 10]]''.<ref name="Departure">{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/5967370/Radio-2-listeners-appalled-at-presenters-sudden-departure.html|title= Radio 2 listeners 'appalled' at presenter's sudden departure|publisher= Daily Telegraph|first= Caroline|last= Gammell|date= 4 August 2009|accessdate= 18 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref> **15 August – [[Malcolm Laycock]] criticises the network's management for abandoning its older listeners and claims he was [[constructive dismissal|constructively dismissed]] by the station, although Radio 2 denies this to be the case. Laycock resigned from his position following a long-running dispute with his producer over the content of his show, and because of issues regarding his salary.<ref name="Maily">{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1206803/A-parting-blast-BBC-Radio-2-s-voice-big-band.html|title= BBC slammed by Radio 2 DJ Malcolm Laycock|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|newspaper= The Mail on Sunday|first= James|last= Tapper|date= 15 August 2009|accessdate= 14 February 2012}}</ref> **18 December – After 27 years, Sir [[Terry Wogan]] presents his final [[Wake Up to Wogan|breakfast show]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8420157.stm|title= Sir Terry Wogan bids farewell to show|publisher= BBC News|date= 18 December 2009|accessdate= 18 December 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091224064256/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8420157.stm| archivedate= 24 December 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==2010s== *'''2010''' **7 January – [[Jonathan Ross]] announces he will leave the [[BBC]] when his contract expires in July.<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8445581.stm|title=Jonathan Ross is Leaving the BBC|publisher=''[[BBC News]]''|date=2010-01-07|accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref> **11 January – [[Chris Evans (DJ)|Chris Evans]] takes over as presenter of the [[Chris Evans Breakfast Show|breakfast show]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8241101.stm|title= Sir Terry to leave breakfast show|publisher= BBC News|date= 7 September 2009|accessdate= 31 December 2009}}</ref> The programme's launch also sees the return of newsreader [[Moira Stuart]] to the BBC after two years away.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/6941385/Moira-Stuart-returns-to-the-BBC-on-Chris-Evans-radio-show.html|title= Moira Stuart returns to the BBC on Chris Evans' radio show|publisher= Telegraph.co.uk|first= Urmee|last= Khan|date= 7 January 2010|accessdate= 14 January 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100110235940/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/6941385/Moira-Stuart-returns-to-the-BBC-on-Chris-Evans-radio-show.html| archivedate= 10 January 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/seealso/2010/01/what_the_critics_say_chris_eva.html|title= What the critics say: Chris Evans' Radio 2 breakfast show debut|publisher= BBC News|first= Mark|last= Savage|date= 11 January 2010|accessdate= 14 January 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100114054858/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/seealso/2010/01/what_the_critics_say_chris_eva.html| archivedate= 14 January 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Simon Mayo]] takes over the [[Simon Mayo Drivetime|drivetime show]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/news/a195527/mayo-bbc-is-marginalising-religion.html|title= Mayo: 'BBC is no}}</ref> **11 March – BBC Radio 2 confirms plans to overhaul its schedule from April. This will include moving two of its longest-running shows, ''[[Big Band Special]]'' and ''The Organist Entertains'' to different timeslots, and switching its comedy hour from Thursday to Saturday evenings – the second time it has done this in 12 months.<ref>{{cite news|first=John|last= Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/mar/11/radio-2-schedule |title=Long-running shows move in Radio 2 reshuffle|publisher= guardian.co.uk |work=The Guardian |date= 11 March 2010|accessdate=1 February 2012}}</ref> **30 April – It is reported that [[Emma Forbes]] has quit as co-host of the Saturday night show ''[[Alan Carr|Going Out with Alan Carr]]'' after a disagreement with her bosses over time off.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1269905/Emma-Forbes-quits-Radio-2-clashing-time-off.html|title= Emma Forbes quits Alan Carr's Radio 2 show after clashing with bosses 'over time off'|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|work= Mail Online|first= Sara|last= Nathan|date= 30 April 2010|accessdate= 30 April 2010| archiveurl= https://archive.is/20120804061037/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1269905/Emma-Forbes-quits-Radio-2-clashing-time-off.html| archivedate= 4 August 2012 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> **5 July – The [[BBC Trust]] rejects BBC plans to close the digital station [[BBC 6 Music|6 Music]] saying there is not a strong enough case for closure.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10507286.stm|title= BBC Trust rejects 6 Music closure plan|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|date= 5 July 2010|accessdate= 5 July 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100706183545/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10507286.stm| archivedate= 6 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> **3 September – BBC Radio 2 announces that ''Dawn Patrol'' presenter [[Sarah Kennedy]] is leaving the network after 17 years. By then she had been absent from the show for several weeks, and would not return to the programme before the schedules were reorganised in October. [[Lynn Parsons]] acts as the show's stand-in presenter for its remaining time on air.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/sep/03/sarah-kennedy-radio-2|title= Sarah Kennedy to leave BBC Radio 2|publisher= Guardian Media Group|work= The Guardian|first= James|last= Robinson|date= 3 September 2010|accessdate= 3 September 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100905064003/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2010/sep/03/sarah-kennedy-radio-2| archivedate= 5 September 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> **2 October – Comedian [[Graham Norton]] takes over the Saturday morning show, formerly hosted by [[Jonathan Ross]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11135947 |title=Graham Norton show to replace Friday Night with Ross |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=31 August 2010 |accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> **6 November – [[Tony Blackburn]] joins to replace [[Dale Winton]] as the regular host of the station's ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'' programme.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/sep/24/tony-blackburn-pick-pops |title= Tony Blackburn to present Pick of the Pops|publisher= Guardian Media Group|work= The Guardian|first= John|last= Plunkett|date= 24 September 2010|accessdate= 13 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101026054226/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2010/sep/24/tony-blackburn-pick-pops| archivedate= 26 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
*'''2011''' **17 January – [[Vanessa Feltz]] takes over [[Sarah Kennedy]]'s early morning show.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/tv-radio/vanessa-feltz-to-take-over-sarah-kennedy-radio-2-show-2141680.html|title= Vanessa Feltz to take over Sarah Kennedy Radio 2 show|publisher= Independent Print Limited|work= The Independent|date= 23 November 2010|accessdate= 27 November 2010}}</ref> **31 January – [[BBC Radio 2]] announces the cancellation of its annual [[BBC Radio 2 Electric Proms|Electric Proms]] season after five years, citing financial considerations.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jan/31/bbc-radio-2-electric-proms|title=BBC Radio 2 axes Electric Proms|publisher=Guardian Media Group|work=The Guardian|first=John|last=Plunkett|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> **4 April – [[Jo Whiley]] joins on a permanent basis to present a new evening show. Jo had been an occasional stand-in presenter since 2009. She replaces [[Mark Radcliffe (radio broadcaster)|Mark Radcliffe]] and [[Stuart Maconie]] who are moving to [[BBC 6 Music]] to present that station's afternoon show.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/feb/01/mark-radcliffe-stuart-maconie-radio-2-6-music|title=Mark Radcliffe and Stuart Maconie switch from Radio 2 to 6 Music|first=John|last=Plunkett|date=1 February 2011|website=the Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **22 June – Radio 2 hosts 2DAY, a day of 12 hour-long programmes to promote some of the station’s specialist output normally reserved for evenings and weekends.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2011/05/bbc-radio-2-to-run-promo-day/ |title=BBC Radio 2 to run promo day |publisher=Radio Today |date=16 May 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2011/06/mixed-response-to-start-of-2day/ |title=Mixed response to start of Radio 2's 2DAY |publisher=Radio Today |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> **28 August – [[Alan Titchmarsh]] presents the final edition of ''[[Melodies for You]]''. The programme, dedicated to popular classic and light music, and part of the station's Sunday schedule since it launched in 1967, was scrapped as the station wanted to change its format for representing the genres.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2011/08/radio-2-drops-titchmarshs-sunday-show/ |title=Radio 2 drops Titchmarsh’s Sunday show |publisher=Radio Today |date=19 August 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2011/08_august/18/melodies.shtml |title=Alan Titchmarsh With Melodies For You on Radio 2 comes to a close |publisher=BBC Press Office |date=18 August 2011 |accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> **11 September – The first [[Radio 2 Live in Hyde Park]] music festival is held in London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]], with [[Gary Barlow]] as headline act.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/corporate2/mediacentre/latestnews/090911barlow |title=Gary Barlow to headline Radio 2 Live in Hyde Park |work=BBC Media Centre |publisher=BBC |date=9 September 2011 |accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref>
*'''2012''' **28 January – [[Zoë Ball]] announces she is stepping down from the Saturday breakfast show. She will continue to provide cover for other presenters on the network.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/01/last-radio-2-saturday-show-for-zoe-ball/ |title=Last Radio 2 Saturday show for Zoe Ball |publisher=Radio Today |date=29 January 2012 |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref> She is replaced on 25 February by [[Anneka Rice]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/02/rice-takes-radio-2-weekend-show-from-ball/ |title=Rice takes Radio 2 weekend show from Ball |publisher=Radio Today |date= 10 February 2012|accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> **6 February – [[Diane-Louise Jordan]] replaces [[Brian D’Arcy]] as host of ''[[The Sunday Hour|Sunday Half Hour]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2012/sunday-half-hour.html|title=BBC – Father Brian D’Arcy steps down from Sunday Half Hour – Media Centre|website=www.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **6 March – Comedian [[Alan Carr]] announces his intention to quit his Radio 2 show ''Going Out with Alan Carr'' so he can devote more time to his television career.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/2012/0307/carra.html |title=Carr quits radio to concentrate on TV |work=RTÉ News |publisher=Rte.ie |date=6 March 2012 |accessdate=7 March 2012}}</ref> **14 April – ***[[Dave Pearce]] joins to host a weekly dance music show. ''Dave Pearce's Dance Years'' will air on Saturday evenings.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/03/dave-pearce-for-radio-2-saturday-nights/ |title=Dave Pearce for Radio 2 Saturday nights |publisher=Radio Today |date=26 March 2012 |accessdate=26 March 2012}}</ref> ***Radio 2 airs a minute-by-minute account of the [[sinking of the RMS Titanic]] to coincide with the 100th anniversary of the disaster.<ref>{{cite news|first=Gillian |last=Reynolds |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9200288/Titanic-Minute-by-Minute-Radio-2-preview.html |title=Titanic: Minute by Minute, Radio 2, preview |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=12 April 2012 |accessdate=14 April 2012}}</ref> **12 May – [[Liza Tarbuck]] begins presenting her first regular show, having provided holiday cover on many previous occasions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/03/liza-tarbuck-gets-radio-2-saturday-nights/ |title=Liza Tarbuck gets Radio 2 Saturday nights |publisher=Radio Today |date=8 March 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Paul |last=Millar |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/media/news/a370162/liza-tarbuck-to-replace-alan-carr-on-bbc-radio-2-going-out-show.html |title=Liza Tarbuck to replace Alan Carr on BBC Radio 2 'Going Out' show – Media News |publisher=Digital Spy |date=8 March 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref> **September – Radio 2 ends the practice of having its own team of newsreaders. This role was taken on by journalists. As a result, [[Colin Berry]] leaves – he had been a newsreader for the station since 1973. **17 October – Radio 2 axes folk presenter [[Mike Harding]] after fifteen years with the network. He will host his last show on 26 December.<ref>{{cite news|author=TV and Radio |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9615551/Radio-2-axes-Mike-Harding-from-folk-role.html |title=Radio 2 axes Mike Harding from folk role |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=17 October 2012 |accessdate=18 October 2012}}</ref>
*'''2013''' **20 January – The Sunday Half Hour is doubled in length but moves from mid-evenings to an early morning slot and is renamed accordingly, to [[The Sunday Hour]]. At the same time [[Clare Balding]] takes over as host of ''[[Good Morning Sunday]]''.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/12/clare-balding-radio-2 Clare Balding to front her first radio show on Radio 2]</ref> **4 August – After a career with Radio 2 spanning more than 40 years, [[David Jacobs (broadcaster)|David Jacobs]] retires.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23407506|title=David Jacobs steps down from Radio 2|work=BBC News|date=22 July 2013|accessdate =22 July 2013}}</ref> **5 October – [[Sara Cox]] joins to host ''Sounds of the 80s'', a new programme dedicated to hits of the 80s.<ref name=RT-2013-09-10>{{cite news |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/09/sara-cox-does-radio-2s-sounds-of-the-80s/ |title=Sara Cox makes Radio 2′s Sounds of the 80s |publisher=Radio Today |date=10 September 2013 |accessdate=3 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005012500/http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/09/sara-cox-does-radio-2s-sounds-of-the-80s/ |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> **1 November – Broadcasting of [[Paul Gambaccini]]'s ''America's Greatest Hits'' is suspended from its Saturday night slot after the presenter is arrested as part of the [[Operation Yewtree]] investigation. Gambaccinini himself took the decision not to go on air following media interest in his arrest.<ref>{{cite news|last=Philipson |first=Alice |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/10421999/BBC-presenter-Paul-Gambaccini-arrested-on-suspicion-of-sexual-offences.html |title=BBC presenter Paul Gambaccini arrested on suspicion of sexual offences |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=1 November 2013 |accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/11/paul-gambaccinis-bbc-radio-2-show-pulled/ |title=Paul Gambaccini's BBC Radio 2 show pulled |publisher=Radio Today |date=1 November 2013 |accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref> Gambaccini will return to the station a year later after it is decided that he will face no charges.
*'''2014''' **7–10 April – As part of the BBC's celebration of the 20th anniversary of [[Britpop]], [[Steve Lamacq]] and [[Jo Whiley]] present a week of Radio 1's long running ''[[The Evening Session]]'' on [[BBC Radio 2]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/03/lamacq-whiley-reunited-on-bbc-radio-2/ |title=Lamacq & Whiley reunited on BBC Radio 2 |publisher=Radio Today |date=17 March 2014 |accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref> **8 May – Radio 2 launches its very first pop DAB station [[BBC Radio 2 Eurovision]]. It returned a year later to cover the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015 contest]]. **October – Radio 2 stops broadcasting a full overnight schedule as part of cost cutting measures. The 3{{nbsp}}am to 5{{nbsp}}am weeknight slot broadcasts repeats of weekly shows.
*'''2015''' **5–8 March – Radio 2 launches its second pop-up station – [[BBC Radio 2 Country]] to cover the annual [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival. The station returned to cover the 2016 and 2017 event. **27 March – Newsreader and continuity announcer [[Alan Dedicoat]] presents his final bulletins for the network after 28 years.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin |first=Roy |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/03/newsreader-alan-dedicoat-to-exit-bbc-radio-2/ |title=Newsreader Alan Dedicoat to exit BBC Radio 2 |publisher=Radio Today |date=24 March 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref>
*'''2016''' **25 February – [[Tony Blackburn]] is sacked by the BBC<ref name="Rawlinson250216">{{cite news|last1=Rawlinson|first1=Kevin|last2=Sweney|first2=Mark|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/feb/25/bbc-tony-blackburn-savile-inquiry-evidence-janet-smith|title=BBC 'parted company' with Tony Blackburn over Savile inquiry evidence|work=The Guardian|date=25 February 2016|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref> and [[Mark Goodier]] takes over as temporary host of [[Pick of the Pops]]. **April – Radio 2 broadcasts its third pop-up station – BBC Radio 2 50s. **9 July – [[Paul Gambaccini]] becomes the permanent host of ''[[Pick of the Pops]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/24/paul-gambaccini-tony-blackburn-radio-2-fearne-cotton-bbc|title=Paul Gambaccini to replace Tony Blackburn on Radio 2’s Pick of the Pops|first=John|last=Plunkett|date=24 May 2016|website=the Guardian|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> **July – [[Trevor Nelson]] brings his ''Rhythm Nation'' r&b show to Saturday nights. He had previously presented a Wednesday evening soul show for the station. **28 October – [[Desmond Carrington]] presents his final show, having presented weekly shows for Radio 2 for the past 37 years.<ref name=ret>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-37518086|title=Desmond Carrington leaves BBC Radio 2 – BBC News|date=30 September 2016|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=30 September 2016}}</ref>
*'''2017''' **9 January – [[BBC Radio 2]] announces that all remaining overnight live programming will be dropped as part of cost-cutting measures. Consequently, the ''After Midnight'' programme, presented by [[Janice Long]] and [[Alex Lester]] will be axed in favour of repeats of shows such as ''[[Sounds of the 60s]]'' and ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'', while an automated service titled ''Radio 2 Playlists'' will air in the 2{{nbsp}}am{{snd}}5{{nbsp}}am slot.<ref>{{cite news|first=Lewis |last=Carnie |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2017/r2-schedule-changes |title=Radio 2 announces overnight schedule changes |work=BBC Media Centre |publisher=BBC |date=9 January 2017 |accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> **25 February – [[Brian Matthew]] presents his final edition of ''[[Sounds of the 60s]]'' for Radio 2, following his retirement due to ill health.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-39089974 |title=Sounds of the 60s: Brian Matthew 'saddened' to leave show after 27 years |work=BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=25 February 2017 |accessdate=25 February 2017}}</ref> **4 March – [[Tony Blackburn]] succeeds Brian Matthew as presenter of Radio 2's ''Sounds of the 60s''. The two-hour show also moves to the earlier time of 6{{nbsp}}am. **9 July – [[Diane-Louise Jordan]] presents ''[[The Sunday Hour]]'' for the final time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Diane Louise Jordan leaves The Sunday Hour|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2017/07/diane-louise-jordan-leaves-the-sunday-hour/}}</ref> **30 September – The 50th anniversary of the launch of [[BBC Radio 2]] (and [[BBC Radio 1]]) is celebrated.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-41414837|title=50 facts about Radio 1 & 2 as they turn 50|first=Mark|last=Savage|date=30 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=17 June 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> The two stations air a joint 90-minute show presented by [[Nick Grimshaw]] and [[Tony Blackburn]], and Radio 2 reconstructs the very first Radio 1 show – Tony Blackburn’s Disc Delivery. **26 November – [[Clare Balding]] hosts ''Good Morning Sunday'' for the final time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2017/clare-balding|title=Clare Balding to leave Good Morning Sunday |work=BBC Media Centre|publisher=BBC|date=26 November 2017|accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref>
*'''2018''' **28 January – After nearly 78 years on air, ''[[The Sunday Hour]]'' is broadcast on [[BBC Radio 2]] for the final time.<ref name=R2Sunday/> **4 February – ''[[Good Morning Sunday]]'' is relaunched and extended into a three-hour programme, presented by [[Kate Bottley]] and [[Jason Mohammad]].<ref name=R2Sunday>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2017/r2-good-morning-sunday |title=A new look for Sunday mornings on Radio 2|publisher=BBC|work=BBC Press Office|date=20 December 2017|accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref> **29 March – [[Lynn Bowles]], who has been reading travel news for the station since 2000, leaves.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43428561 |title=Lynn Bowles: 'I'm leaving Radio 2' says travel presenter |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=16 March 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> **8 May – Long running specialist music programmes ''[[The Organist Entertains]]'' and ''Listen to the Band'' are broadcast for the final time – the former had been on air since 1969. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/schedules/p00fzl8v/2018/05/08|title=BBC Radio 2 schedule 8 May 2018|website=BBC Radio 2}}</ref> **10 May – The final edition of the ''[[Radio 2 Arts Programme]]'' is broadcast, ending after 28 years on air. **14 May – A new weekday evening and overnight schedule launches. [[Jo Whiley]] joins [[Simon Mayo]] to present an extended teatime show with Jo's former slot now occupied by specialist music and documentaries. [[Sara Cox]] launches a new late evening show and live overnight broadcasting resumes with a new midnight to 3{{nbsp}}am show presented by [[O.J. Borg]]. **18 May – [[Gary Davies]] joins to replace Sara Cox as presenter of ''[[Sounds of the 80s]]''. **3 September – [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] reveals live on air he is to leave his [[The Chris Evans Breakfast Show|Radio 2 breakfast show]] at the end of the year.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-45394576 |title=Chris Evans to leave Radio 2 breakfast show for Virgin |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=3 September 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> A month later, Radio 2 announces that [[Zoë Ball]] will take over as presenter of the ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show|Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]'' in January 2019.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-45724304|title=Zoe Ball to present Radio 2 Breakfast Show|date=3 October 2018|publisher=BBC|accessdate=3 October 2018|work=BBC News}}</ref> **22 October – Radio 2's unpopular ''Drivetime Show with Simon Mayo and Jo Whiley'' is to end after a backlash from listeners. [[Jo Whiley]] will move back to an evening slot, while [[Simon Mayo]] will leave Radio 2, but he will continue his [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] film review programme.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-45938829 |title=Simon Mayo and Jo Whiley Radio 2 Drivetime show to end |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=22 October 2018 |accessdate=22 October 2018}}</ref> **29 October – [[Sara Cox]] is named as Radio 2's new Drivetime presenter, replacing [[Simon Mayo]]. Although a date for her start is yet to be confirmed, it is announced that the show will return to its two hour format from 5.00pm to 7.00pm.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-46012177 |title=Sara Cox to present Radio 2 Drivetime show |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=29 October 2018 |accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> **8 November – [[Rylan Clark-Neal]] is named as presenter of the Saturday teatime show and the Saturday evening slot vacated by Trevor Nelson will be filled by some of the displaced weeknight specialist shows.<ref>[https://www.a516digital.com/2018/11/rylan-slots-into-final-part-of-radio-2.html Rylan slots into final part of Radio 2 schedule shuffle puzzle</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=January 2009}} A '''tombeau''' (plural '''tombeaux''') is a musical composition (earlier, in the early 16th century, a poem) commemorating the death of a notable individual. The term derives from the French word for "tomb" or "tombstone". The vast majority of tombeaux date from the 17th century and were composed for [[lute]] or other plucked string instruments. The genre gradually fell out of use during the 18th century, but reappeared in the early 20th.
==History== "In instrumental music, ''tombeau'' signifies a musical 'tombstone' (French ''le tombeau'' = tomb). The musical genre of tombeau is generally connected with music for the [[lute]] of the 17th and 18th centuries. Of some 60+ surviving pieces, most are intended for the [[lute]] or [[theorbo]], 5 for the baroque [[guitar]], 7 for the [[viola da gamba]] and 3 for [[harpsichord]]. The earliest example of this genre seems to be the ''Tombeau de [[René Mezangeau|Mezangeau]]'' (1638) by French lutenist [[Ennemond Gaultier]]."<ref>http://polyhymnion.org/tombeau</ref>
"Musical predecessors are memorial pavans like those by [[Anthony Holborne]] (''Countess of Pembrokes Funeralle'', 1599). In France, where this musical genre emerged first, strong influence of literary models, particularly of memorial poems that were popular from the 16th to the end of the 17th centuries, may have been another important factor."<ref>http://polyhymnion.org/tombeau</ref>
"The tombeau preeminently comes in two forms, as a slow elegiac [[allemande]] grave in 4/4 or as a [[pavane|pavan]], a tri-partite [[renaissance dance]] already long out of date for the era of tombeaux, but with all the trappings of the allemande (cf. [[Denis Gaultier]], ''Tombeau pour M. [[Racquette]]''). There are also a few unique tombeaux that appear as [[gigue]]s; that is because the gigue grave resembles the allemande in a number of respects."<ref>http://polyhymnion.org/tombeau</ref>
"As opposed to the Italian [[lamento]], the tombeau should not have used expressive elements of mourning, which were skeptically viewed in France. Nevertheless, certain typical [[onomatopoetic]] features were used: repeated note motifs depicting the knocking of Death at the door, ascending or descending [[diatonic]] or [[chromatic]] [[musical scale|scale]]s which depict the soul's tribulation and transcendence. Froberger's [[Lamentation]] on the Death of Ferdinand III or the Meditation sur ma Mort Future would be a prime example of such a form. Some tombeaux include a motif of four descending notes, a metaphor for grief given influential expression by John Dowland in his [[Lachrimae]] (1604). These genres offered many suitable expressive characteristics: the suspirans figure (a three-note upbeat), dotted rhythms, particularly in repeated notes, and slow-moving harmonies in the minor mode whose gravity is heightened by a tendency to settle on pedal points. Later examples also tend to use chromatic progressions related to the lamento bass. The few courante tombeaux exploit the same rhythmic features in triple metre."<ref>http://polyhymnion.org/tombeau</ref>
"Developed by Parisian [[lutenist]]s ([[Denis Gaultier]], [[Charles Mouton]], [[Jacques Gallot]], [[François Dufault]]), the genre was soon taken over by [[clavecin]]ists ([[Johann Jakob Froberger]], [[Louis Couperin]], both on the death of their friend [[Charles Fleury|Blancrocher]] in 1652) and was then spread into Central Europe ([[Jan Antonín Losy]], [[Sylvius Leopold Weiss]])."<ref>http://polyhymnion.org/tombeau</ref>
The tombeau genre went into decline at the end of the 18th century. It reappeared in the 20th century with [[Maurice Ravel]]'s ''[[Le tombeau de Couperin]]'' (1919). Other 20th century tombeaux include [[Manuel de Falla]]'s ''Le tombeau de [[Claude Debussy|Debussy]]'' for solo guitar, [[Arthur Benjamin]]'s ''Le tombeau de Ravel'' for clarinet and piano, and the last movement of ''[[Pli selon pli]]'' by [[Pierre Boulez]]. In the 21st century a series of tombeaux was written by [[Roman Turovsky-Savchuk]].<ref>http://www.sineris.es/tombeaux2.html</ref>
==List of tombeaux==
===Lute and other plucked string instruments=== * [[François Dufault|François Dufaut]]: ''Tombeau de Monsieur Blancrocher'' * [[Jacques Gallot]]: ''Tombeau de Condé'', ''Tombeau de Madame'', ''Tombeau de Turenne'' * [[Denis Gaultier]]: ''Tombeau de Monsieur Blancrocher'', ''Tombeau de Mlle Gaultier'', ''Tombeau de Mr. Lenclos'', ''[Pavane ou] Tombeau de Mr. Raquette'' * [[Ennemond Gaultier]]: ''Tombeau de Mezangeau'' * [[Jan Antonín Losy]]: ''Tombeau'' * [[Charles Mouton]]: ''Tombeau de Gogo'', ''Tombeau de Madame'', * [[Robert de Visée]]: ''Tombeau de Mr. Francisque Corbet'', ''Tombeau de Dubut'', ''Tombeau du Vieux Gallot'', ''Tombeau de Mr. Mouton'', ''Le Tombeau [de Tonty]'', ''Tombeau de Mesdemoiselles de Visée'' * [[Sylvius Leopold Weiss]]: ''Tombeau sur la mort de M. Cajetan Baron d'Hartig'', ''Tombeau sur la mort de M. Comte de Losy'' * [[Jacques de Saint-Luc]]: ''Tombeau sur la mort de Mr [[Francois Ginter]]'' * [[Roman Turovsky-Savchuk]]: ''Tombeau sur la mort de [[Omelyan Kovch]]''
===Viola da gamba=== * [[Charles Dollé]]: ''Tombeau de [[Marin Marais]]'' * [[Marin Marais]]: ''Tombeau de M. [[Jean-Baptiste Lully|Lully]]'', ''Tombeau pour Marais le cadet'', ''Tombeau de M. Meliton'', ''Tombeau de M. de Ste-Colombe'' * [[Monsieur de Sainte-Colombe]]: ''Tombeau 'Les regrets'', ''Tombeau pour [[Monsieur de Sainte-Colombe]] le père'' * [[Roman Turovsky-Savchuk]]: ''Tombeau de [[Telemann]]'', ''Tombeau de [[Jean-Baptiste Forqueray|Forqueray]]''
===Harpsichord=== * [[Jean-Henri d'Anglebert]]: ''Tombeau de M. de Chambonnières'' * [[Louis Couperin]]: ''Tombeau de Monsieur Blancrocher'' * [[Johann Jakob Froberger]]: ''Tombeau fait à Paris sur la mort de Monsieur Blancrocher''
